description:
1. User try to  boot a new vm by click the button "+ Launch Instance"  in dashboard web->project->compute->instances.
2. But the button "+ Launch Instance"  is disabled and shows "quota exceeded".
3. Then user go to dashboard web->project->compute->overview perspective, but find Instances,VCPU and RAM haven't exceed 
the quotas. In this case, it's shows like below:
Instances
Used 8 of 10
VCPUs
Used 18 of 20
RAM
Used 512MB of 50.0GB 
This will confuse the user, is there anything incorrect?

root cause: 
I think one of the root cause is that the current project have another work, such as rebuilding vm, which obtail some quotas and mark
the 'reserved' fields(nova->quota_usages table) to a none zero value .
So I select *  from nova.quota_usages where project_id = 'current project id', and find thati in  the row 'cores' , the 'reserved' = 2. Because of this,  the VCPU is actually Used 10 of 10. 
Excepted result:
The 'reserved' quota should also be taken as an used quota ,and so in dashboard web->project->compute->overview perspectiv, it should shows as below:
VCPUs
Used 20 of 20.
title: dashboard displays wrong quotas

comments.content:
Thanks for taking the time to file a bug! I'm currently working to reproduce your issue, but I need more information:

1) Can you provide more detail as to how you got to your current state? It sounds like you have 8 instances, is that correct? Have you recently deleted any instances or launched any instances that failed?

2) What version of Nova are you running? (Kilo, Liberty, Mitaka, current master, etc)

3) What happens when you launch an instance using the command line client? Do you also get the quota error in that case?

comments.content:
Thanks for taking a time to view this notes.The answers for your comments:
1) yes, I already have 8 instances, and the total quotas is 10.  Not sure whether any instances have been deleted that failed, because there are too many users belongs to this project. But I saw a "rebuild" task is running in the dashboard, maybe the
one instance is being rebuild, so the 'reserved' column is set to a none zero value.
2)The environment is installed by others people, I check some code in this release, it seems the icehouse release.(2014.1) 
Or do you have any method/command to ensure the version?
3)I launch the instance using command and got following logs:
OverLimit: Quota exceeded for instances: Requested 1, but already used 10 of 10 instances (HTTP 413) (Request-ID: req-c2e1f366-ed73-4050-8523-5d524733b3c9)
ERROR: Quota exceeded for instances: Requested 1, but already used 10 of 10 instances (HTTP 413) (Request-ID: req-c2e1f366-ed73-4050-8523-5d524733b3c9)

Not sure whether the info above will help, but I have a workaround to re-produce this bug:
For example, if your total quotas of instances is 10, and 8/10 used, you can do this:
mysql;
use nova;
UPDATE `quota_usages` SET `reserved`=2 WHERE  `project_id`='827fb1414de740569efd53580bafc2f0' and `resource`='instances' LIMIT 1;
Then, refresh your dashboard in the web browser, you will get this bug.

comments.content:
Right now, I'd say reproducing on master (mitaka at least) is top priority. If it's not an issue, then it's fixed. Icehouse is pretty old at this point.

The reason for (2) was explained, there is some other operation going on for the project that has taken a reservation on quotas, which then goes into calculating the overall usage, see:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/used_limits.py#L57

When you recreate this, what does this show you?

nova limits --tenant <project id> --reserved?

That should show you the quota limits plus total usage (included used quota and reserved quota).  If that adds up to 10 when you recreate, then I think the bug is in Horizon for not using the --reserved option when displaying quota usage.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~mriedem

comments.content:
nova absolute-limits --reserved
...
| totalCoresUsed          | 10    |
| maxTotalCores           | 10    |

You can see the totalCoresUsed is up to 10.   So the bug is in Horizon for not using the --reserved option when displaying quota usage.

commit 35eb25a955f116cbd42e9952ba47cee61c0759aa
Author: Itxaka <email address hidden>
Date:   Thu Apr 21 12:18:30 2016 +0200

    Make sure we always get all limits
    
    When checking with nova for the absolute limits
    we were not taking into account the reserved
    quotas (i.e. instance in rebuilding will take
    cpu and ram) so this could lead to wrongly
    thinking that the user could launch more instances
    that its quota allowed. It also made the overview
    page display wrong quotas as it didnt took into
    account those reserved resources.
    
    Change-Id: If51470d185ddc122acbdf4cf0d0fd952f3f791a0
    Closes-bug: 1561310
